text: The CAMERA follows a SIXTEEN YEAR OLD GIRL, long hair, pr Sunday church dress, walking toward a peaceful farmhouse. the door she lifts the knocker. The door opens slightly. girl turns and looks past the camera at her MOTHER, sitti in an old Plymouth idling in the driveway. Her mother shr motions for her to go inside.
The girl walks through the downstairs rooms. In the kitch the PHONE is OFF the hook. The girl looks back toward the open front door. She turns toward the stairs, climbs them
She walks down the hall to a BEDROOM DOOR at the end. The door is slightly ajar. She knocks, then enters the room.

The girl's POV: the CAMERA pans across the bedroom of a h school coed. We see the desk, the bureau, the bed. On the bed lies NANCY CLUTTER, her wrists and legs bound in rope SHOT in the head. There is blood on the wall. The sixteen year-old girl stands immobile. Before she starts to screa
Trees ring the edge of a field.
Buildings lit against the night sky.
Camera follows group of partygoers as they mount the stai Truman Capote, Barbara (very tall), Rose, Christopher,  Williams.
The friends are standing in the crowded kitchen -- people are coming in and out -- talking and drinking and laughin

So Jimmy Baldwin tells me the plot  of his book, and he says to me: the  writing's going well, but I just  want to make sure it's not one of  those problem novels. I said: Jimmy,  your novel's about a Negro homosexual  who's in love with a Jew -- wouldn't  you call that a problem?
Laughter.
Susan's father had a minor heart  attack, so she's writing more erotic  poems about death and sex.
It's so tiresome.
Hmm. What rhymes with angina?
Laughter. We see Truman watching everyone laugh. GRAYSON  notices, leans in to him. As the rest of the group contin talking, we come closer, hear their conversation.
How's your writing?
Oh, I've got a million ideas of what  to write next -- I just have to choose  one.
Really?
No.
Their attention is pulled back into the group as:
Who would I want to play me? Natalie  Wood.
Too fat.
Audrey Hepburn?
Not bad. Sort of middle-class.
When a movie is made of my life I  know exactly who I want as me... (beat) Marilyn Monroe.
Barbara cracks up, chokes on her drink.
Truman sits with his coffee, reading the New York Times. article catches his eye. He sits up straight, folds the p over, reads it.

C/U of article being snipped out of PAGE 39 of the Times, November 16, 1959. As the page gets turned around with ea snip, we see a small PHOTO of a middle-aged man wearing  glasses, with the caption: "FOUND DEAD: Herbert W. Clutte a wealthy Kansas farmer..." We read the headline: "WEALTH FARMER, 3 OF FAMILY SLAIN. Parts of the story: "HOLCOMB,  Kan., Nov. 15 (UPI) -- ...wheat farmer, his wife... two y children found shot today..."
Truman on the phone.
New Yorker magazine.
William Shawn, please. (he listens) Adorable one? All of a sudden I know  what article I'm going to write for  you next.

Truman on the phone, on a long cord, travels between the  study and the kitchen as he talks to William Shawn. We he pieces of the conversation, and see Truman in different p of the room as he says each bit.

...never had anything like this happen  to them before. They're used to  sleeping at night with the doors  unlatched.... (laughs) Yes, we should buy stock in Master  Locks -- all of Kansas will be in  the hardware store tomorrow.
Jump to -
They have no idea who the killer is.  But it doesn't matter who the killer  is -- what matters is who the  townspeople imagine the killer is.  That's what I want to write about.
Jump to -
I'm gonna need some help... I'm  thinking about Nelle -- she can  protect me...

JACK DUNPHY (strong, Irish-American, ten years older than Truman) -- his longtime boyfriend -- enters the front doo with a bag of groceries, stops in the hall. He sees Truma on the phone. Truman looks at Jack, though he's still spe to Shawn --
I want to leave tonight...

location: TRAIN TRACKS, OUTSKIRTS OF NEW YORK CITY

text: A train barrels toward us, its headlight bright. The trai roars past, away from the city.
Truman hurries through the train, checking his ticket wit the sleeper cabins. His long SCARF trails behind. His lon cashmere COAT practically brushes the floor.

location: TRUMAN AND HARPER LEE'S CABIN, TRAIN

text: Truman opens the door. Inside the cabin his childhood fri from Monroeville, Alabama, NELLE HARPER LEE (yes, that Ha Lee), is reading. She looks up, deadpan --
I figured you'd missed it.
Nelle is a year younger than Truman, dowdy in dress, but  smart, tough, sensible. Truman smiles.
God I'm glad you agreed to come.  You're the only one I know with the  qualifications to be both a research  assistant and personal bodyguard. (then, noticing) Oh, Nelle, you poor thing.
He tries to spruce up her limp silk scarf.
Off. Truman. Off. (holds his hands) I'm happy to see you too, but I can  still whip your behind.
TWO BLACK PORTERS enter, one with an enormous TRUNK  (Truman's), the other with a sensible SUITCASE (Nelle's).
(reading tags) Mr. Truman Capote, Miss Nelle Harper  Lee. Where would you like these,  sir?
That one up there and that one on  the floor.
He tips them.
What all did you bring?
Thank you greatly, sir. It's an honor  to have you with us. If you don't  mind my saying, your last book was  even better than the first --
You're sweet.
Just when you think they've gotten  as good as they can get.
Thank you. You're very kind.
(to Nelle) Ma'am.
The PORTERS leave. Nelle is stunned. Truman fiddles with trunk locks, his back to Nelle. Silence, then:
You're pathetic.
Truman doesn't answer.
You're pathetic.
What?
You paid them to say that.
Truman won't look at her. She whacks him.
You paid them to say that!
(squealing) How'd you know? How did you know?!
"Just when you think they've gotten  as good as they can get."
You think that was too much? (laughter) I thought that was a good line.
More laughter. More smacking of Truman. Then it is quiet.
Pathetic.

location: TRUMAN AND HARPER LEE'S CABIN, TRAIN

text: Nelle's awake, but still in her bunk, looking out the win at the Kansas plains. Truman's dressing, watching her.

TRAVELING SHOTS of harvested FIELDS, grazing LIVESTOCK,  solitary FARMHOUSES. The TRAIN chugs across the Kansas flatlands. SHOTS of SIGNS outside Garden City: "World's Largest Free Swimpool" and "Howdy, Stranger! Welcome to Garden City. A Friendly Place. "
Truman and Nelle rent a car. People stare.
Nelle drives past the main square, Truman in the passenge seat. Truman looks at a photo in THE GARDEN CITY TELEGRAM
Alvin Dewey, Kansas Bureau of  Investigation. KBI.
Truman and Nelle check in. People stare. Nelle notices.
Truman and Nelle trot up the COURTHOUSE STEPS.
Truman approaches the GUARD DESK.
Mr. Alvin Dewey, please.
Third floor. In what used to be the  Sheriff's Office.
Truman CURTSIES.

In the reception area, ALVIN DEWEY and the two other KBI  AGENTS assigned to the Clutter case are getting their jac on and straightening their ties. They've completely taken over the office. They are: HAROLD "Brother" NYE (34); and ROY "Curly CHURCH (60 - bald). They all smoke. Sheriff WALTER SANDERSON -- 60's, kind, overweight -- is  office-less (though he and his wife DOROTHY still live on the fourth floor of the Courthouse.) WALTER lurks in the  background, nowhere to go, emptying one of many FILLED  ASHTRAYS, BOTHERED by the SMOKE. Truman and Nelle enter a

The wife said no more smoking in the  house. I told her, "Fine. Walter's  got a couch upstairs in his apartment.  I'll stay with him and Dorothy till  we're done here." (to Walter) I've got my bag and a carton of  cigarettes in the car.
WALTER looks uncomfortable. Dewey shakes his head at Chur
Roy.
Mr. Dewey. Truman Capote from the  New Yorker.
Silence. The Agents stare at him.
Hello.
Silence. Nye is looking at Truman, particularly puzzled.
Bergdorf's.
Sorry?
The scarf.
Oh. (then) Nice.
Thank you. (turns to Dewey) I wonder when we could arrange an  interview? Some time to talk.
Dewey stubs out his cigarette.
About what?

We're not looking for any inside  information -- I don't care one way  or another if you catch whoever did  this -- I'm writing an article not  about the Clutter killings, but how  they're affecting the town, how you  all are bearing up --
I care.
Excuse me?
I care. (puts on his hat,  pulls out another  cigarette) I care a great deal if we catch  whoever did this.
Yes --
As do a lot of folks around here.
Of course.
Dewey walks out. Nye and Church start out after him.
(to Church) New Yorker?
You have press credentials?
What's the New Yorker?
Magazine.
Magazines don't give out --
You can come to the news conference  with the rest of them. (tips his hat to Nelle) Sears and Roebuck.
Nelle and Truman are left alone.

Packed with PRESS from all over the Midwest, as well as l Finney County CITIZENS. Dewey's leading the press conference from a FOLDING TABLE set up in front of the Judge's bench, flanked by the two  other KBI Agents. He's got a cigarette burning in an asht Truman and Nelle stand in the back.

I'll talk facts but I won't speculate.  The main fact here we need to be  clear on is not one, but four people  were killed. A lot of folks say Herb  Clutter had to be the main target  because he was dealt with the most  brutally --
Had his throat cut.
(a moment) Yes. We'd all like to know why. But  it could've been any one of the family  they were after. We just don't know --
You've identified the murder weapon?
Wounds indicate a shotgun, close- range, but no casings were found.
Twelve-gauge, hunting --
Right.
They were all shot in the face?
Dewey looks at the journalist. Then, evenly:
No. Nancy in the back of the head.
Is there any evidence of, I'm sorry,  sexual molestation of the women?
No.
Anything else stolen?
Kenyon's radio seems to be the only...
The boy was sixteen?
Fifteen. Nancy was sixteen.
It's her friend that found them?
Laura Kinney.
Spell that?
I assume you're okay with the Laura  part. K-I-N-N-E-Y. But, please, leave  her be.
Lots of folks try to talk at once, one OLD MAN makes hims heard above the rest:
There's talk of a bunch of Mexicans,  a whole bunch of Mexicans...

(standing, stubs out  cigarette) George, it's good to see you again.  I do have an opinion whether this  was the work of one man or a whole  bunch, as you said, but it doesn't  matter a whole lot whether it was  Mexicans or Methodists or Eskimos.  We're going to find whoever did this.  Four good people from our community  are dead. Let's remember that. Okay  with you? (holds up a notice) The West Kansas Farm Committee's  offering a thousand dollar reward  for information leading to an arrest.  Please print that. (moving to the exit) Thank you all for coming.
The room is immediately noisy as Dewey makes his way to t door, pulling a pack of cigarettes from his pocket, follo by Church and Nye. He's about to step out when Truman cat his eye. Dewey exits.
Nelle drives while consulting a MAP. Truman is leaning ba looking out at the passing farms through the window. He s almost to himself.
Mr. Dewey's protective of the  Clutters. I wonder how well he knew  them...
Nelle glances over at him. He doesn't notice.
He was foxy with that old man. (turns to Nelle) Are you ever gonna let me drive?
Truman, you're a menace. You can  barely see over the wheel.
Truman looks back out the window at the farms, leans back
This make you miss Alabama?
(rolling window down,  shakes his head) Not even a little bit.
He leans his head out, closes his eyes.

Nelle pulls their car to the side of the COUNTY ROAD whic fronts the CLUTTER FARM. We recognize the FARMHOUSE as th one in which Nancy Clutter was found dead. A HIGHWAY PATR (20 years old) sits in a CRUISER parked up the driveway. CRIME SCENE TAPE marks the perimeter of the property. Tru and Nelle get out of their car, stand at the foot of the  driveway, gazing at the lonely farmhouse.
A gorgeous fall day. Crowds of kids arriving at school. M are SOMBER. As Truman and Nelle walk toward the kids, som look warily at Truman and give him a wide berth.
Hello.
Kids back away. Nelle notices. She leaves Truman, walks u to a group of THREE GIRLS.
Morning.
Hi.
Can any of you tell me where I'd  find Laura Kinney?
Oh, um...
The girl glances toward the school entrance where LAURA K (who found Nancy Clutter's body) walks with DANNY BURKE ( 17).
(gently) Is that her? With the tall boy?
Yeah. With Danny Burke.
Danny Burke? (Girl #2 nods) Thank you.
As Nelle leaves, Girl #1 turns to her friend:
Oh, quiet yourself, Janice.
Nelle sees Truman on his way toward Laura, calls out --
Truman. Truman --
Truman doesn't hear. She watches Truman approach them. La backs away. Danny leads her off. Nelle walks over to Trum looks at him for several moments.
These folks live their lives in a  particular way. You need to consider  adapting yourself to that fact.
What --
-- I'm gonna find out where those  two kids live. Maybe you'll let me  do that alone?
Nelle leaves. On Truman, as the bell rings and the mass o teenagers starts to enter the school.
Truman walks alone, sees the Gilbart Funeral Home. He rem his hat, slips past the few people standing outside.
Warm but slightly tacky. Some people are engaged in hushe conversation at the reception area. Truman slips past, in the back room.

No people, low light. Four CLOSED CASKETS at the back of room. Truman walks over slowly. After a moment, he checks make sure he's alone. Then he LIFTS THE TOP of one of the caskets. It's Bonnie Clutter's body, in a long-sleaved na blue dress; but her head is wrapped in layers and layers white cotton gauze, and lacquered with a shiny substance like an enormous cocoon. Truman stares.

Truman on the PHONE to Jack in Brooklyn. One of Truman's  trunks is open, displaying bottles of liquor, packaged an tinned gourmet food, and stacks of unused yellow legal pa He drinks, standing at the window.
I think I scared a friend of yours  this morning. He came looking for  you while I was writing.
You hate my friends.
I wouldn't say hate. So long as they  don't knock on my door.
I saw the bodies today.
Which?
The Clutters. I looked inside the  coffins.
That's horrifying.
It comforts me -- something so  horrifying it's freeing. It's a  relief. Normal life falls away. (beat) But, then, I was never much for normal  life --
No, you weren't.
People here won't talk to me. They  want someone like you, like Nelle.  Me they hate.
I can't think of a single quality I  share with Nelle.
Well --
Maybe manliness.
My point exactly.
It's why I left the Midwest in the  first place. I knew I could only  find someone like you in New York  City.
On Truman, gazing at the EMPTY TOWN SQUARE below.

A SHOPKEEPER sweeps the sidewalk. There are THANKSGIVING  DECORATIONS in his shop window. A SCHOOL BUS picks up a SMALL BOY at the intersection of DIRT ROAD and the paved COUNTY ROAD. A SMALL BRIDGE over the Arkansas river. Below them, men a sifting the riverbed with nets, moving slowly downstream.

Nelle waits by the FRONT DESK. The ELEVATOR DOORS open an Truman emerges. He is DRESSED SOBERLY -- NO LONG SCARF, N LONG COAT. He walks toward Nelle, then TURNS as if he's a runway model, walks away, turns again and walks back. He  stops a few feet in front of her. Nelle refuses to smile.
Let's go.
Danny Burke walks down the road with a bookbag over his  shoulder. Nelle approaches him, Truman keeps his distance
Danny? (Danny stops) Would you mind terribly if I walked  with you for a bit?
He shrugs. They walk together.
Laura opens door to Truman and Nelle.
Nelle and Laura Kinney sit at the table. Truman stands at the counter.
I thought you were from the FBI with  your long coat.
Is that so?
That's why I ran off.
I've been getting a lot of that  lately.
Truman smiles. Laura smiles back, amused, a bit comforted
It's fine talking to you all.  Practically nobody around here wants  to talk since what happened.
Folks have been through a rough patch.  Including you. (Laura nods) Nancy was your best friend.
She was my best friend.
They're quiet for a few moments.
How has Danny been?

Pretty shattered. Nothing terrible  ever happened to him before. Nancy  just started wearing his ring again  after this huge fight -- Mr. Clutter  was trying to get her to end it 'cause  Danny's Catholic.
What were the Clutters?

Methodist. Danny was the last person  at the house that night. That's why  Mr. Dewey's keeps interviewing him --  they don't think he had anything to  do with it -- just to see if he  remembers anything unusual and all.
People in town seem to wonder if he  was involved.
That's been real hard for Danny.

Oh, it's the hardest -- when people  have a notion about you and it's  impossible to convince them otherwise.  Since I was a child folks have thought  they had me pegged because of the  way I look and the way I talk. They're  always wrong. (looks at her) Do you know what I mean?
Laura stares at him and nods. He's clearly struck a chord
I want to show you something.
She goes in the door to the GROUND FLOOR APARTMENT. They her through the LACE CURTAINS getting something from her  DESK, which is stacked with books. Truman whispers to Nel
Not one person here understands her.
Laura returns. She hugs a SMALL BOOK to her chest. After moment, she holds it out to them.
Maybe you'll get a better picture of  Nancy. And the family.
What is this?
It's her diary.
Nelle and Truman walk quickly back to the hotel. Nelle ha the diary open.
"Danny here tonight and we watched  TV. So nice just having him sit with  us. Left at eleven. P.S. -- He's the  only one I really love."
She turns the page. The rest of the book is blank.
And that was that.
The end of a life.

Nelle typing. Truman is propped up on pillows on the bed, scrunching his eyes to remember what was said that aftern then writing quickly on one of many YELLOW LEGAL PADS, ha the pages of interview dialogue to Nelle. He's exhausted. Nelle stops typing a moment, looks through the pages Trum has handed her:
"Shattered."
"Pretty shattered. Nothing terrible  ever happened to him before. "
He pushes some pillows aside and lies down.
I have 94 percent recall of all  conversations.
94 percent.
I've tested myself.
(scans some of what  he's written) I hate that you're better than me at  this.
She turns back to the typewriter. She types. Truman lies  there, looking at the ceiling for a few moments. He close his eyes. Nelle knows without looking --
Don't you dare close your eyes on my  bed.
No answer. She keeps typing.
Stand up and walk out that door. Go  to your room if you're gonna sleep.  Truman. Truman.
Nelle turns to look at him. He's asleep. She goes back to typing. Under her breath:
Crap.

Truman drinks coffee alone, sleepy. He takes a SMALL BOTT of HOT-PEPPER TABASCO from his jacket pocket and shakes i over his EGGS. He replaces the bottle in his jacket. Nell walks into the lobby from upstairs, heads for Truman.
What right do you have being tired?  You were snoring blissfully --
I don't snore --
-- while I lay there, hating you --
You don't hate me.
Not much. (She sits. Truman  holds out a NOTE) What? (takes it, looks) Marie Dewey?... We've got somewhere  to go for Thanksgiving supper.
Apparently Detective Foxy's wife has  a better opinion of me than Detective  Foxy.
Ding Dong. We see the FRONT DOOR open. Reveal MARIE DEWEY pretty, 35, dressed primly -- and her two boys: ALVIN JR. (9), and PAUL (6), lurking behind, curious. Marie smiles.
You came.
Reverse onto Nelle... and Truman, dressed in a DARK SUIT, hair neatly combed, like an Exeter schoolboy attending a  funeral. Nelle smiles.
Hi.
Nelle nudges Truman, who hands over his gifts: a BOTTLE O J&B, and a PACKAGE of GOURMET SPICED NUTS.
(soberly) Thank you for having us.
(mock serious) Thank you. (then:) Get yourselves in here. (turns and walks into  the house) Alvin! Get your pants on. They're  here.
On Nelle and Truman, surprised.
A FOOTBALL GAME plays on the television. No one's watchin We can HEAR Alvin on the phone in his study at the back o the house.

Truman and Marie at the stove. Nelle sits at the kitchen  table. Truman has his jacket off and an apron on, as does Marie. They are peering into a POT OF BLACK-EYED PEAS. Ma is shaking in drops of HOT PEPPER TABASCO.
More. More.
Alvin will hate this.
Yes, but we who know the truth will  love it.
(laughs) I have to stop. (then) I cannot believe you're from New  Orleans. I miss it so much.
I only lived there for a short while  but my Mama was born and bred.

You know something -- Alvin pretends  he doesn't know who you are, but the  minute you came to town he read your  books. He had one of his men pick up  "Breakfast at Tiffany's" in Kansas  City 'cause it's banned from the  library here.
What did Mr. Dewey think?
He liked it more than he's willing  to admit.
How very foxy.
Marie smiles at that word used to describe her husband.
Mama would've put in half the bottle  by now.
Beat.
Alright, one more shake.
Alvin walks toward the kitchen. He smokes. He looks exhau He hears SQUEALS of laughter.
Alvin enters. They all stop laughing and look at him. nod to Truman and Nelle.
Hello.
Hi.
Silence. Marie sips her drink.
How you doing, foxy?
She cracks up.

The remains of dinner. The kids have left. The bottle of sits on the table, half-empty. Marie's a bit drunk. Every PLATE is clean except for Alvin's, on which sits a MOUND uneaten black-eyed peas. Truman is mid-story.

I was writing the script as they  were filming, all that time in Italy.  I'd work like mad all day long and  then dash down to the bar around  midnight to hand in the next day's  scenes. Humphrey had just about moved  into the hotel bar --
(whispers to Alvin) Humphrey Bogart.
Alvin knows.
-- where he and John drank every  night --
(to Alvin) John Huston.
Alvin knows.

-- and I mean drank, like famished  water buffaloes. Well -- I'd only  just handed them the final scene  when the bellhop told me I had a  phone call. It was my stepfather,  Joe Capote, calling to say that my  mother had died. I flew home to New  York -- terribly distraught -- but  when I got to the apartment I could  see that Joe was in even worse shape  than I was. He grabbed my hands and  sat me down at the kitchen table,  and he said to me, "Talk. Talk about  anything, any subject in the world.  Don't worry whether it will interest  me or not. Just talk so I won't break  down." And I did. He couldn't bear  to be alone with his thoughts. It  was too painful.
It's quiet for a moment, then Marie looks at Alvin.
It's been a hard couple weeks for  Alvin. He and Herb Clutter were good  friends. From church.
Marie --
Oh come on, Alvin. These are good  people.
Finally, Dewey looks at Truman and Nelle.

Alvin shows Truman and Nelle the CRIME SCENE PHOTOS from Clutter murders. We see the four corpses, BOUND and SHOT, the bloody footprints in the Clutter basement. Truman and Nelle stare at the photos of Nancy and Kenyon. Then, quie
Who would put a pillow under the  boy's head just to shoot him? Why  would they tuck Nancy in?
(surprised by the  insight) I want to know the same thing.
Truman hands Nelle one of the photos. She looks at it --
Twisted notion of tenderness.
Truman and Nelle are leaving. Alvin and Marie stand in th front door. Nelle kisses Marie.
Thank you.
So many of my friends would love to  meet you.
That'd be fine --
(to Dewey) You don't have to worry. I'm not  going to write about this until  everything's over.
I'm not worried. I know what room  you're in at the hotel. And I know  where you live in Brooklyn.
Truman smiles.

MUSIC: "Have yourself a Merry Little Christmas..." Main  Street, CHRISTMAS LIGHTS in the TREES. The HARDWARE STORE, with Santa Claus DECORATIONS in the w and a "ONE WEEK LEFT TO BUY YOUR GIFTS..." sign.
Truman and Nelle walk with PETE HOLT (70, very frail) on Clutter property. Apples rot on the ground, the trees are bare, signs of disrepair are beginning to weather the hou

(re the apples) I'd of picked them up but I haven't  been myself. Mind you, I make the  walk out here every day, check the  house, make sure the pipes don't  freeze -- that sort of item. The  least I can do for Mr. Clutter.
How long have you worked here?
1940 -- a lotta years. The wife too,  cleaning the house. Cooking.
Well, she's marvelous. Lunch was  wonderful.

(ignoring this) She had a hard job after what all  happened. Cleaning. I burned most of  the rest -- mattresses -- too far of  a mess. (then, looks at them) I've asked around some -- if anyone's  looking for a strong hand.
They don't know what to say. Finally, he looks away.
I don't think they'll be able to  sell the place till they catch the  ones that did it. (beat) That's what I hear anyhow.
Silence as the three of them look out over the barren fie

Just the bed-frame -- the mattress is gone. Truman and Ne find her Bible on the bedside table, her bookmark, see th painting of Jesus walking on water. Pete Holt stands off the side, waiting patiently.
Through the front window we see a Christmas tree in the l
Jazzy Christmas music on the RADIO. Nelle sits in the big armchair with a drink. She laughs. We HEAR Jack on the ph
You're celebrating.
We see Truman wearing a YELLOW SILK SHORT ROBE with white lace, bare legs. He's on the phone and walking, for Nelle enjoyment, back and forth, like a runway model.
Remember Nelle's manuscript she sent  me in New York?
Mockingbird. Killing a Mockingbird.  You said it was good.
And I was right. She just heard  Lipincott wants to publish it.
(pause) Well. Jesus. That's terrific. Tell  her congratulations.
Congratulations. (covers phone, mouths  to Nelle:) Jealous.
Just promise you'll be home by  Christmas.
I can't leave now Jack -- I mean it  was hard at first, but now I'm  practically the mayor.
He vamps. Nelle laughs.
Alright.
I want to come home -- I do. Though  if they catch whoever did this, who  knows what -- I'll probably be here  til next Christmas.
Right. I'll let you go.
Jack, we'll go away this spring to  write. Maybe Spain...
Alright, Truman.
Bye. (hangs up) The poor boy misses me.
Goes to the mini-bar to fix a drink.
Truman.
Nelle.
You remember when we were kids?
I was never a kid. I was born fully  formed.
I had no idea what a homosexual was.  But I knew whatever they were, you  were one of 'em.
Truman puts down his drink and marches out of the room, s the door. Nelle's unsure whether she really insulted him. From the HALL, we hear a WOMAN SHRIEK, and a MAN saying:
Oh. Uh. Oh. Excuse us.
Truman runs back in, shuts door. They crack up.
Tasteful Christmas lights strung on the BUSHES. A WREATH the FRONT DOOR.

Truman, Nelle, Marie and Alvin. Drinks. A FULL ASHTRAY on the coffee table in front of Alvin. He's distracted, smok Marie holds a WOMEN'S MAGAZINE, checking what Truman says with what's written there.
(quickly, as if  reciting) -- girdle up -- no extra bulges --  if you're dressed right for him when  he gets home, the evening should be  smooth sailing. Bon voyage, gals.
I can't believe you got this whole  page -- I only read it to you once! TRUMAN
I've trained myself.
Truman looks at Nelle. TRUMAN
I have 94 percent  recall.
(laughing) You cut that out.
Alvin stubs out his cigarette -- though it still burns. H stands.
You believe that Alvin?
Impressive.
He walks out. Silence.

I'm sorry. He's upset. (stubs out cigarette) -- smoking three packs a day. (then) Two men did it. They know who. One  of them used to have a cellmate who  gave him up for the thousand dollar  reward. They passed through Kansas  City last week writing bad checks --  by the time Alvin's boys got up there  they'd skipped out again.
Where to?
They have no idea.
Christmas dinner. Truman, Nelle, Marie and Alvin have jus sat down. They wait for the Dewey boys -- Alvin Jr. and P We hear them in the living room horsing around.
Alvin. Paul. Now.
It's quiet for a second. Then something crashes and break
Damnit. (gets up, goes) Come here.
Alvin ...
Phone RINGS.
Alvin Jr. Get over here.
Dad, the phone.
Paul. Back to the table.
Dewey returns to the dining room, pushing Paul ahead of h
Sit.
Alvin Jr. enters.
Dad?
Tell them we're at dinner, Alvin.
Dad?
Not now, Alvin.
Alvin Jr. leaves. We hear the PHONE being HUNG UP. Alvin returns and sits. They all get ready to say grace, then:
You need to call the Chief of Police  in Las Vegas when you have a minute.
Everyone looks at Dewey.
OVER BLACK SCREEN we hear the voice of a RADIO ANNOUNCER.
...This is KERG radio, Garden City.  A friendly broadcast from a friendly  place. Our lead story:

Slowly, the sounds of a CROWD emerge in the background. FADE UP ON: HIGH SCHOOL kids sitting on the hood and fron seat of a CHEW parked at the edge of a CROWD of 200 peopl Truman watches. It is COLD. A fat, shivering CO-ED reads headline in the Kansas City Star: "Police Fear Lynch Mob. The CAR RADIO is on.

...newsmen from six states have joined  scores of Kansans as they await the  arrival of confessed killers Perry  Smith and Richard Hickock. KBI  officers have been driving the Clutter  family's brutal killers nonstop  from...

Truman moves from the car into the large crowd. Old ladie ranchers; local businessmen; moms with kids; journalists  INTERVIEWING citizens; photographers lined up at the bott of the COURTHOUSE STEPS. We hear snippets of conversation we pass. A CITIZEN is being interviewed by a JOURNALIST; MOM WITH BABY standing with a FRIEND; a MIDDLE-AGED man i an overcoat CRYING silently. Truman approaches Nelle and Marie Dewey, standing togethe at the curb in front of the courthouse, near the  photographers. They are talking quietly, turn to Truman -
Hey.

We hear LOUD CROWD NOISE at the south end of the square. CONVOY of FOUR CARS enters the square. It pulls around to the front of the courthouse. STATE TROOPERS spill out of lead and rear CARS. Nye gets out of the second car. He op the back door. The crowd falls SILENT. Two state troopers get DICK HICKOCK -- handcuffed, pale -- out of the car an lead him up the steps. FLASH. FLASH. Dewey and Church open the third car's back door. Silence. They retrieve PERRY SMITH. Perry is extremely SHORT, STRO ODDLY BEAUTIFUL, with the dark skin and hair of his Ameri Indian mother, and the pug features of his Irish father. he stands, he has trouble straightening his stubby LEGS, if they are arthritic. Truman stares.
(whispers to Truman) Motorcycle accident. He broke them  and they never healed right. (Truman looks at her) Alvin told me.

Truman watches Perry, transfixed. Perry seems terrified o the crowd, all the faces, like a child. Perry scans the c His eyes fall on Truman. FLASH. FLASH. Truman and Perry l at each other as Perry is led slowly past. At the top of steps the COURTHOUSE DOORS slam shut.
FADE IN: Truman knocks on the door, a NEWSPAPER, a BOOK, a PAPER BAG in his hand. On the door it says "SHERIFF'S  RESIDENCE - PRIVATE". Dorothy Sanderson opens the door.
Truman Capote.

Dorothy Sanderson. I figured you'd  be left alone this morning by that  hard-working husband of yours. (holds up bag) So I have breakfast. (holds up paper) I have news. (book) And I have literature. My friend  Jack mailed me the book you wanted.
He presents book. Dorothy, flattered, takes it, reads the inscription inside.
"For the maiden of the Midwest, the  priestess of the plains, the queen  of the kitchen: my first novel.  Truman."
It is "Other Voices, Other Rooms" and we see on the back it the INFAMOUS JACKET PHOTO of Truman at 23 draped sexil on a couch. Truman curtsies. The PHONE RINGS.
You're too much. Go on into the living  room, lemme grab that -- it's been  ringing all morning.
Truman walks into the residence. To the left is the kitch to the right is the living room. Truman looks back at Dor she's still on the phone. He heads for the kitchen.

Truman walks slowly through the doorway of the large kitc On the far side of the kitchen is a JAIL CELL. Inside the cell is PERRY SMITH. (Now we know why Truman came here.) Truman STARES. Perry doesn't see him -- he's resting his  head on a small table, the tip of his THUMB in his mouth. The chair seems too tall for Perry. He looks like a lonel kindergartner, told to take his afternoon nap. After seve moments, Dorothy enters, flustered:
Oh. Truman. I meant in there. (points to living  room) I... um...
Perry sits up quickly, rubs his legs.
It's the women's cell. It's hardly  ever used. But they wanted to, um,  separate... Please. Let's sit in the  living room. I'll set up in the living  room.
She gathers a tray of Truman's PASTRIES, and COFFEE CUPS.
Come.
She goes -- Truman starts to follow, then lingers.
They put you in the women's cell.
Among other indignities.
Perry's voice is oddly high, whispery -- special words ar precisely enunciated.
Well... she's a good cook.
She's scared of me.
I think so am I. A little bit.
Are you? (a moment, then:) You have any aspirin? My legs --
Dorothy's in the doorway.
Um. Truman? All set.
Truman looks at Dorothy, looks back at Perry.
I'm sorry.

Judge ROLAND TATE, white-haired, imperious, bangs his gav The packed crowd quiets down. Perry and Dick sit at the  defense table chewing JUICY FRUIT GUM. Next to them: thei aged court-appointed lawyer, Franklin Weeks (70). Dick wears a SHIRT AND TIE. Perry wears jeans rolled up a the cuff, his SHIRT OPEN at the collar. He draws on a pie of paper with a STUBBY PENCIL -- a rather good picture of LARGE PARROT. Truman sits with Nelle, watching Perry --
(murmurs) His feet don't touch the floor.

In the matter of the State of Kansas  v. Richard Eugene Hickock and Perry  Edward Smith this Court has been  informed by counsel -- Mr. Weeks --  that defendants wish to waive their  right to Preliminary Hearing. Mr.  Hickock, is that your wish?
Hickock looks at Weeks. Weeks nods. Hickock stands.
(unconvincing) Yessir. Yes.
Hickock sits. Truman whispers to Nelle --
Why are they doing that?
Mr. Smith.
(stands... then:) I ask that the waiver be effectuated.
Judge Tate looks at him for a moment --
So noted. (bangs gavel) We're adjourned.

Crowd gets up. Much talk. Truman watches Perry and Dick  through the forest of bodies. They are led away in handcu Franklin Weeks stands slowly, then begins gathering his t he's old and it takes him ages to collect his papers. Tru watches.
Truman knocks. He holds a PIE. Dorothy answers.
Mr. Capote.
(offers pie) Madame Sanderson.
Is that for the two of us to share?  Or for me to eat alone while you  talk to our guest?
Truman is caught. He smiles.

Truman sits near the bars of the cell. Perry draws on a s of paper at the small table. Dorothy watches from the doo to the living room. The BOOK Truman gave to Dorothy lies the floor next to Perry's meticulously made bed.
Was it your choice to waive the  hearing?
Perry doesn't answer. Dorothy checks her watch, leaves. T takes a bottle of BAYER ASPIRIN out of his pocket.
You still need some? (Perry doesn't move) Give me your hand.
Perry extends his hand through the bars. As Truman shakes some aspirin into it --
I could kill you if you got too close.
Perry puts the aspirin in his mouth, CHEWS THEM, holds ou his hand for more. Truman gives him more, which Perry put in his pocket for later.
Would you like some water?
Perry shakes his head. Silence.
Mrs. Sanderson lent you my book --
He said we'd curry favor with the  Judge if we waived our rights.
Who did?
The lawyer.
Okay.
Truman nods, not wanting to push this any further. Perry  picks up the book, holds it out through the bars.
Your picture's undignified. People  recall first impressions.
What's been your first impression?
You want something.
From you?
Dorothy pokes her head in from the living room.
Truman. Walter's gonna be home soon.
(to Perry) I just want permission to talk. (then) Has anyone else visited?
Perry doesn't answer.
Truman --
Will you tell me if you need anything?  I can have whatever you want sent  from New York. (no answer) Will you do that?
On Perry, considering whether to trust this man.
Phone RINGS, WILLIAM SHAWN answers (50, New Yorker editor conservatively attired) at a desk looking onto 44th stree
William Shawn.
Gorgeous?
Truman.
INTERCUT to Truman in a PHONE BOOTH outside the COURTHOUS
I'm writing a book. It's too much  for a single article -- this town,  the killers most of all -- you will  be stunned by Perry Smith --
Why? What has he --
Not much yet, but I know. I can sense  him. He's desperately lonely,  frightened... I have questions --  are you ready?
Would it matter --
How much more money can you send me?  How quickly can you get Dick Avedon  out here to take some pictures?
INTERCUT to WILLIAM SHAWN'S OFFICE. On Shawn -- he doesn' know how to begin to respond.

Perry has been placed in an adjoining cell for the aftern He COMBS his greased hair in a mirror. A camera FLASHES. Nelle and Truman sit outside the cells. Franklin Weeks do off to the side. RICHARD AVEDON -- small, dark, wiry,  flamboyant -- is snapping photos of a bare-chested Hickoc in the next cell, particularly his TATTOOS, while Hickock chatters away.
Perry, honey. You look terrific...
Perry is embarrassed, glances over at Truman. FLASH.
Calm yourself down, sweetheart.

Perry glances at Nelle. She MOTIONS to him that his SHIRT buttoned wrong. Perry fixes it, looks back at her. Hickock notices Truman gazing at his tattoos -- the one o his CHEST: the word PEACE, with a cross radiating rays of light.
Be patient, Capote. Maybe later  they'll send you my skin.
I have the perfect place for it,  over the hearth.

Hickock smiles. FLASH. Truman looks over at Perry, sittin alone. Truman starts to remove his TIE. PHOTOS, in quick succession: Of Hickock pulling up his sl to reveal his tattoos. Of Perry combing his HAIR. FLASH. GRINNING CAT on Hickock's hand. FLASH. Perry looking dire at the camera. FLASH.

Series of shots in and around the courthouse: TITLE UP:             "One month later" An officer approaches down a long hallway. A janitor clea the basin of the water fountain. Spectators are drawn int the courthouse. The officer opens the courtroom doors. A  crescendo of sounds.

Spectators take seats. The jury files back into the box.  Perry and Dick chew gum. Perry wears TRUMAN'S TIE, and dr on a pad with a NEW SET OF COLORED PENCILS -- another PAR quite beautiful, now YELLOW. Nelle and Truman sit togethe
Where'd Perry get the art set?
Truman shrugs. Nelle raises her eyebrows. Judge Tate GAVE loudly, looks to the jury.
Members of the jury. Have you reached  a verdict?
(stands) Yes sir.
Defendants rise.
Perry and Dick stand. Judge Tate turns back to the Forema
Perry Edward Smith and Richard Eugene  Hickock stand accused of four counts  of the crime of murder in the first  degree. Have you reached a unanimous  verdict?
We have, your honor.
What is your verdict?
Guilty. On all counts.
Have you unanimously reached a  sentence.
We have, your honor.
What is the sentence?
Death.
Judge nods, the foreman sits. Judge turns to Perry and Di

Perry Edward Smith and Richard Eugene  Hickock. You've been found guilty of  four counts of murder in the first  degree. You will be taken to the  state penitentiary at Lansing. No  later than midnight, May 13 of this  year, nineteen hundred and sixty,  each of you will be hanged by the  neck until dead. So ordered.
He GAVELS. Perry and Dick are set upon by Sheriff's Deput and led out. Photographers crowd them. Dick turns to Perr
Alright, partner. Least now we're  not the only killers in Kansas.
Perry looks at him, utterly lost. FLASH.

Nelle sits at the window, smoking. Truman in the armchair holding a drink. They've been up all night. Their bags ar packed. Also -- a few packed boxes of written -- in yello notepads and many typed pages. Truman glances at his watc
You think he slept at all?
Nelle looks over at him.
I need to see him before we go.
Truman sits next to Perry's cell. Perry lies on the bed,  staring at the ceiling.
They're going to transfer you up to  Lansing today. You'll have to make  sure to put me on the visitor's list.  Otherwise I can't see you.
No response.

Will you do that? I'm going to help  find you a proper lawyer. You need a  serious lawyer for an appeal. (no response) They took Dick last night. I need  you to get him to do the same thing --  put me on the visitor's list. Will  you do that, Perry?
Perry closes his eyes.
Perry.

location: TRUMAN AND JACK'S HOUSE, LIVING ROOM

text: FADE UP ON the sounds of a HUGE PARTY in progress. We see home-made BANNER reading "Return to Civilization!" The CA follows NELLE as she walks through the crowd: Gays, strai smoke and noise. Society women, slender and beautiful; BE BARON pontificating to CHRISTOPHER ISHERWOOD.
Nelle. Kudos on "Kill the Bird." Is  that it?
Close enough. Thanks.
William Shawn talks to a MUCH TALLER WOMAN.
He hasn't written a word yet, though  he says it's the nonfiction book of  the decade...
We HEAR Truman before we see him:
He's little, but terrifying --
We see Truman in the corner entertaining a small group. J Dunphy stands off to the side. Nelle settles next to Jack
He's as short as I am. And almost as  pretty. I'd be with him right now  but he's being given new  accommodations --
Guests laugh.
Most people assume he's a monster. I  don't see him that way. The book I'm  writing will return him to the realm  of humanity -- it's the book I was  always meant to write...
Nelle and Jack stand back, watching.
Watch out. This is the start of a  great love affair.
Oh yes. Truman in love with Truman.
Truman is being interviewed over lunch.
...I was in Marilyn's apartment just  last week. I had to break it to her  that, of the four Matisses hanging  on her wall, two were upside down.
The REPORTER laughs. A waiter passes. Truman taps his gla
Another. (to reporter) To answer your question, I'm following  "Breakfast at Tiffany's" by blazing  a different path -- by inventing an  entirely new kind of writing: the  non-fiction novel.
You have a subject?
Truman takes a last sip of his drink -- utterly serious n

On the night of November 14, two men  broke into a quite farmhouse in Kansas  and murdered an entire family. Why  did they do that? It's been suggested  that this subject is tawdry -- it's  not worthy of literature. I disagree.  Two worlds exist in this country --  the quiet conservative life, and the  life of those two men -- the  underbelly, the criminally violent.  Those worlds converged that bloody  night. I spent the past three months  interviewing everyone in Kansas  touched by that violence. I spent  hours talking to the killers -- and  I'll spend more. (waiter brings his  drink) Researching this work has changed my  life, altered my point of view about  almost everything. I think those who  read it will be similarly affected. (he sips) Such a book can only be written by a  journalist who has mastered the  techniques of fiction --
You're speaking of yourself.
You're really very clever.
Truman sits in bed, writing on a yellow LEGAL PAD, surrou by PILES of notes. He squints his eyes, concentrating. Ja enters, delivers a CUP OF COFFEE. Truman doesn't notice.
Truman is rifling through the boxes, looking for particul notes. He can't find what he needs. The phone RINGS.
Jack and Truman walk.
Perry's decided to appeal. He claims  their attorney was incompetent --  that he never raised the issue of  temporary insanity.
So you find them a new lawyer.
They're facing execution in six weeks,  Jack. They need someone to argue  whether or not that's right.
Okay.
I'd also like to see them alive,  yes, thank you very much. I need to  hear their story.
They walk in silence for a few moments.

If you met him you'd understand.  It's as if no-one's ever asked him a  single question about himself. He's  so... damaged -- and strange --  unexplored... (then) I don't trust this Hickock fellow.  Perry's the only person who can  describe to me what happened that  night. I need to hear him say it.
Just be careful what you do to get  what you want.
I'm finding them a lawyer.
Truman. You're finding yourself a  lawyer.
Truman drives alone, concentrating intently. He has to st to see over the dashboard.
A turreted, Civil War-era fortress an hour's drive from K City. Truman pulls up to the GUARDHOUSE.

Truman waits alone, looking at the lone decoration: a cam poster, showing a fat man in a suit grinning while holdin shotgun. Across the bottom it reads: WALK TALL WITH KRUTC A YOUNG PRISON GUARD sticks his head out of the office do
Warden Krutch will see you now.

Wood-paneled walls, government-issue desk. On the wall be the desk is a CHART -- a racial accounting of the current inmate population. It reads: WHITE - 1405, COLORED - 360, MEXICANS - 12, INDIANS - 6. WARDEN MARSHALL KRUTCH is fat, coarse, sweaty even in win And it's spring. He's running for Congress -- there are  "KRUTCH FOR CONGRESS" bumper stickers laying around the  office. He's enjoying a chance at a little publicity. The YOUNG PRISON GUARD stands quietly by the wall.
We do well by our boys. Showers once  a week. Feed em good. We'll be feeding  Perry Smith in the infirmary soon if  he don't eat. Get the food in through  his arm.
What are you talking about?
Hasn't eaten in a month. But it's  not his right to kill himself. It's  the People's right. The People of  this State. And that's who I work  for, the People. You can write any  of this down.
No one told me.
Yah. Won't eat.
When can I see him?
(checking desk calendar) How about you come back Thursday?
No. That's no good. I need to see  them now, then whenever I want for  as long as I want.
Not how we do things here.
Pause.
I see.
Truman glances at the campaign stickers, the young prison guard, then back at Krutch.

I understand what a burden unlimited  visitation might be -- on this  institution, and on the People who  pay for it. I want to be clear that  I don't expect the citizens of  Leavenworth County to have to shoulder  that burden.
Truman reaches into his jacket, pulls from it an ENVELOPE STUFFED with CASH. He lays it on the desk.
To be dispensed as you see fit.
Krutch is stone-faced as he regards the money. Finally:
I didn't know where to count your  boy -- being half-Indian. I did him  a favor though. (points to race chart) Counted him White.
You're a kind and generous man.

The second floor of a small building in the corner of the prison complex. Decrepit. The one hall is lit by mesh-cov BARE BULBS in the ceiling. Twelve cells -- six on each si Each is 7 by 10 feet, with one small, high WINDOW covered bars and wire. The YOUNG PRISON GUARD opens the heavy GAT at the end of the hall and shows Truman in. They walk down the row of cells. In one of them we notice Lowell Lee Andrews (20, white, spectacled, ENORMOUSLY FAT peering at his own face 4 inches from a mirror. Dick is leaning against the bars of his own cell. He smil
My hero.
Hello.
Thanks for your help with the lawyer.
That's fine.
You must be desperate for a story to  come all the way out here.
Mr. Capote. You're entitled to go  in. You may, um, go in. If you wish.
Truman hesitates for a second.
You want to see Perry. Go ahead.
Thank you.
Truman walks to the next cell.
Ask me, he's just trying to prove  the insanity defense.

Truman sees Perry, gaunt, lying on his cot, almost comato Perry's rather striking drawing of a LARGE YELLOW PARROT  sits propped on his table. An UNEATEN LUNCH TRAY lies on floor -- a cockroach runs over it. Truman watches, distur
Camera follows Truman as he walks down an aisle with a sm WICKER BASKET. He stops, looks at a shelf.

Truman waits in the check-out line behind a MOM paying fo her groceries. Her SON (3) stands next to her legs, weari a little cowboy hat and cradling a TOY GUN to his chest. sucks his thumb. Truman and the boy look at each other.

Truman sits on the chair, his WICKER BASKET on the table. has spread out a cloth napkin. A GUARD watches from outsi the cell. Perry lies completely still on the cot. Truman  takes out jars of BONNET BABY FOOD, inspects the labels.
(to Perry) I don't care what your plans are for  yourself...
He decides on the CUSTARD jar. He opens it, takes a plast BABY SPOON from the basket.
But you're gonna wake up enough to  tell me what you did with my tie.
He spoons a bit into Perry's mouth. The GUARD walks away. Truman leans close to Perry, whispers:
It's okay. It's Truman. It's your  friend.

Perry sleeps. Truman stands against the wall watching him He has cleaned up the basket of food. He walks over to Pe desk, sees two handwritten notebooks on it: THE PRIVATE D OF PERRY EDWARD SMITH and PERSONAL DICTIONARY. Next to th he sees a pencil SELF-PORTRAIT Perry drew. It's very good Truman touches it.
Perry sleeps. Truman sits on the chair watching, waiting. Perry opens his eyes, looks at Truman.
Perry is sitting up a bit, Truman helps him sip a cup of  water. Perry lies back down. He's looking at Truman.
How'd you learn to draw like that?
Perry closes his eyes.
Truman drives through the KANSAS STATE PENITENTIARY gate, waves to the Guard.

Perry sits on the bed, cleaned up, wet hair neatly combed looking at a few OLD SNAPSHOTS he has saved in a handkerc Truman sits in the chair across from him. Perry hands him photo of his mother. Perry speaks quietly.
Before she had us. Before she started  drinking.
Who took care of you as a child?
Orphanage. Me and Linda.
That's your sister?
Perry nods. Truman waits for more. It doesn't come.

We're not so different as you might  think. I was abandoned repeatedly as  a child. My mama'd drag me along to  some new town so she could take up  with another man she'd met. Night  after night she'd lock me in the  hotel room -- Mama'd turn the latch  and tell the staff not to let me out  no matter what. I was terrified --  I'd scream my head off -- till finally  I'd collapse on the carpet next to  the door and fall asleep. After years  of this she just left me with  relatives in Alabama.
Who raised you up?
My Aunts. (Perry nods) That's when I met Nelle -- she lived  next door. (looks again at the  photo, hands it back) Your mother was Indian?
Cherokee.
Drinking was not a good thing for  her.
No tolerance for it.
And your father?
No tolerance for him either.
Truman's laughs, surprised by the joke, though it's uncle whether Perry meant it as one. He stares at Perry.
What I can't decide is if you  understand how fascinating you are.
Perry doesn't respond, then --
I'm sorry about your tie. They took  it away from me because we're all on  suicide watch. It's why the lights  stay on at night.
I hope we're past that now. You had  me worried.
Okay.
I don't care about the tie. It's  just a pity because it looked so  good on you.
Perry leans in, motions toward Dick's cell, lowers his vo
Be careful of Ricardo. I think he  wants you all to himself.
Alright --
But he's naturally mendacious -- not  to be trusted -- if he had a hundred  dollars he'd steal a stick of chewing  gum.
You wouldn't.
Perry shakes his head. Then, Truman nods toward Perry's  notebooks.
I want to take your notebooks with  me -- I want to read them.
Perry hesitates.
If I leave here without understanding  you, the world will always see you  as a monster. I don't want that -- I  don't see you that way.
A moment, then Perry reaches for the NOTEBOOKS, hands the to Truman. Then he hands Truman the DRAWING he did of him
I tracked my father down in Alaska.  I was 14. One day I said to him,  "Mom's dead." I could see it. A week  later we got the news. She finally  drunk herself to death.
Truman regards Perry. Then he looks at the drawing --
This is remarkable.
Sometimes you see a thing -- how it  really is.
On Truman holding the drawing, looking at Perry.
Truman walks quickly to his car, holding Perry's DRAWING NOTEBOOKS. At the car, he looks back at the dark jailhous
Truman at the desk, PERRY'S TWO BOOKS next to a LEGAL PAD already filled with notes. He's on the PHONE with Nelle,  paging through the PERSONAL DICTIONARY captivated by it.

He trusts me -- that's why he gave  it to me. He's given me absolutely  everything. (paging through Diary) You should see his drawings, Nelle,  how good he is. He wants so badly to  be taken seriously, to be held in  some esteem.
INTERCUT with Nelle, in pajamas, sitting on the porch of home in Monroeville, smoking.
Do you?
Do I what?
Hold him in esteem?

Well... he's a gold mine. I mean  he's told me his entire life, and  now it's all here for me to write  down -- All of the history I need.  His entire life in this Diary. His  dead mother. A brother and sister  killed themselves.
You tell him your mama did the same  thing?
I tell him everything. We've been  talking our heads off the past month.  Sometimes, when I think how good my  book can be, I can hardly breathe.
Huh.

(finds what he wants) Here's what I wanted to read to you:  "If Called Upon to Make a Speech:" --  this is exactly what I was talking  about -- a speech just in case he's  ever recognized for an achievement:  "If Called Upon to Make a Speech: I  can't remember what I was going to  say for the life of me. I don't think  ever before have so many people been  so directly responsible for my being  so very, very glad. It's a wonderful  moment and a rare one. Thank you!" (beat) There's an exclamation point on the  end of that thank you, in case you  didn't catch it... (silence) Where'd you go?
We hear Nelle exhale her cigarette.
Christ. I guess it stopped being  funny.
I never said it was. (turns a page) Listen to this...
Truman is eating breakfast with Alvin Dewey. A WAITRESS  refills their coffees.
(to waitress) Thanks.
She leaves. An uncomfortable silence. Then:
You're nothing if not hard-working.
You look good, healthy again.
Not a chance.
Dewey taps a cigarette out of his pack.
I've decided on a title for my book.  I think you'll like it -- very  masculine. "In Cold Blood."
(lights the cigarette) That refers to the crime or the fact  that you're still talking to the  criminals?
The former, among other things.
I see.
They eat for a moment. Then:
I've been wanting to ask if you'll  let me look at your investigation  notes.
That lawyer you helped find for your  friends got them a hearing at the  Kansas Supreme Court --
I heard this morning.
-- on the issue of inadequate counsel.
Alvin. Do you not want me to look at  your notes? You are permitted to say  no.
(rises, takes out  wallet) I'll tell you what: if those boys  get off, I'm coming to Brooklyn to  hunt you down.
Truman can't decide whether Dewey is kidding or not. Dewe puts money on the table.
I have to be in court at nine o'clock.
He walks away. Over his shoulder:
Call Roy Church. He'll show you what  you want to see.
Truman walks down the hall. He passes Dick's cell. Dick i lying in bed. Dick rises and smiles widely at Truman.
Hey, hey...

Truman smiles, puts HIS FINGERS TO HIS LIPS, continues pa He stops outside Perry's cell. Perry (looking MUCH HEALTH is drawing at his table -- a picture of the HUGE YELLOW P swooping down from the sky. Truman watches for a few mome then Perry looks at him.
The Guard locks Truman inside with Perry.
Thank you.
Truman looks at the Guard -- he leaves.
It was as much for me as for anyone.  I couldn't bear the thought of losing  you so soon.
We're going to be able to use your  book for our case. You'll write we  never got to raise our insanity plea.  You wrote how terrible the lawyer  was?
I haven't written a word yet.
Beat.
What have you been doing?
Research. Waiting to talk to you.
All right.
I had hoped --
What are you calling it?
The book? (looks directly at  him) I have no idea.
Pause.
If I'm going to write about you --  if I'm going to determine how to  write about you -- you need to tell  me about that night at the Clutter  house.
Perry just looks at him.
Perry.
Perry shakes his head.
Why? Do you worry what I'll think?
Perry looks away. A long moment.
Is that it?
Silence. Then:
Dick says you know Elizabeth Taylor.
I know a lot of people.
Truman gives up for now. Sees the PICTURE OF THE YELLOW B on the desk.
What is that you keep drawing?
You must hate having to come to this  place --

Perry, I have invitations to be in  Morocco, Greece... I choose to be  here. Those people have everything,  all their prayers have been answered,  yet they're more desperate than ever.  I prefer to be here with you.

(looks at Truman;  evenly) I was ten, I wet the bed, the nuns  at the orphanage hated the smell.  First month one of them found me  shivering -- just trying to get  through the night. The Sister pulled  back the covers and shined her  flashlight to see what I'd did. The  sheets were wet. She hit me so many  times with that flashlight she broke  it. (he shrugs) That night I dreamed about the yellow  bird. Tall. Yellow like the sun. It  picked me up and it clawed the Nun's  eyes and it lifted me into the sky.
They look at each other.
Truman on the street outside the club at a PAY PHONE. He  talks with Jack in Brooklyn.
I'm just missing this one piece,  Jack. Be patient with me.
How long is that gonna take? Why  don't you try leaving him alone for  a while? Come to Spain. You can always  visit him later.
I don't know.
Well, I'm off. I've got my own writing  to do.
Do it in Brooklyn. Wait for me.
Too many people around. (beat) I'll leave the address on the kitchen  table. Truman, what do you do there  when you're not with him? -- It must  be awful.
Truman's watching a YOUNG GUY standing outside the bar,  looking at him.
Think about what I said. Join me  when you can.
I will. I will. Bye.
Truman follows the YOUNG GUY into the bar.
Truman sleeps. He OPENS HIS EYES in bed. Turns to the bed table to see the drawing of Perry looking at him.
A young drifter stands alone on an empty street corner. H checks a pay phone for a coin. It's empty.

Perry is lying on his cot reading an ADVENTURE MAGAZINE - something to do with finding buried treasure off the coas of Mexico -- and sucking on the tip of his thumb. After a moment he STARTLES and looks up. Truman stands outside his cell. He holds a stack of books Perry's PERSONAL DICTIONARY and DIARY, and a new WEBSTER' DICTIONARY and THESAURUS.
I didn't see you. Jesus, you... (stands, tucks in  shirt) Come in. Where's the guard?
I can't. I brought you some things,  but I have to fly back East.
When?
An hour. I'm sorry.
You can't.
I'm sorry.
Who are you going there to see --
(from next cell) Capote, get it straight in your book --  we never intended on killing that  family --
I told him that.
No premeditation --
I told him!

Perry searches the cell for something else to give to Tru to keep him there. Then, he stops. He has nothing left to give, and is unwilling to talk about that night at the  Clutters. He becomes very still. Truman speaks gently --
Your writings are magnificent. I  hope these help you do more.
No response. Truman places the books on the floor just ou Perry's cell -- Perry's writings in one stack and the new dictionaries in another right next to it.

I have so much material -- from the  trial, from our visits, your journals.  I have to organize it all, and I  have to start the process of writing. (no response) I'll visit soon. Perhaps this fall. (backing away) I miss you already. Write me every  five minutes.
He turns and goes. We stay with Perry as Truman leaves. W hear Dick speak to Truman.
Be good now.
Hear Truman's footsteps receding. Then, a long shot of th hallway as the Guard lets Truman out the gate at the end the row. Silence.
Perry looks down at the books sitting on the floor outsid his cell. He crouches, puts his hand through the bars and touches the cover of the new dictionary. He's alone.
Over black -- the sound of a JET airplane -- loud, then  passing.
FADE IN: BRIGHT WHITE SKY. Sounds of seagulls. Ocean, san cottage houses in greenery set back from the beach.

The house Jack rented. Jack types on the upstairs deck. T pulls up in an OLD TAXI. Jack looks out over the railing the street. Jack emerges on the FRONT PORCH as Truman wal up the path with his bags. They look at each other. Then  Truman looks around at the incredible garden, the ocean i the background, and starts to LAUGH.
Title up:              "January, 1962" Sound of a MANUAL TYPEWRITER over black.
FADE IN on the peaceful outside of the house. Sound of TY
More typing. A PHONE rings. CAMERA tracks slowly through pretty, tiled living room, toward a DOOR at the far end.

Truman at his DESK, surrounded by piles of filled YELLOW  PADS, NOTE CARDS, an open TRUNK of random notes. He is at the MANUAL TYPEWRITER. The phone is on the floor, ringing He types. The phone rings. Exasperated, he picks up.
What.

Truman. I was supposed to be home  for dinner with my wife three hours  ago -- I have not been able to tear  myself away from your book. It's  that good. It's not good, it's  astonishing. This first half is  astonishing. If the second half lives  up to this it, -- it -- how much is  left to do?
INTERCUT with Shawn's OFFICE at the New Yorker, NIGHT. Sh has a stack of manuscript pages on his desk.
I'm already well into the third part,  but I -- I can't finish that till I  convince Perry to describe the night  of the killings to me. I was planning  to visit this fall, see --
I think you need to talk to him now.
And we all need to see how this ends  for the final part. I can't finish  the book till I know what happens.  If Perry and Dick are executed it's  one thing -- and if not, well --
Truman. You got your ending --
I really don't know --
The Kansas court denied their appeal.  It came over the wire on Friday. You  need to talk to Perry now. He'll be  dead by September. I'm sorry, I know  how much you've come to care about  him.
Truman is completely immobile.
Truman?
Right. Yes. Right.
I want to set up a reading for you  in the fall, in New York. We'll build  some interest, and we'll publish in  the fall.
On Truman.
Truman at the stove watching his tea water heat up. Jack  enters with a HUGE BASKET of WINE and GROCERIES.
Plums. Thank god. We have nothing in  the house.
He takes one from the basket. Jack starts to unpack food.
Why aren't you working?
I knew you couldn't be depended on  to stock the kitchen.
Truman looks at him blankly.
What would we feed our famous guest?
Oh, Jesus. I completely forgot.
He helps Jack put away the groceries. Then:
(utterly nonchalant) Plus -- I finished my novel yesterday.
Truman looks at Jack, smiles widely.
Truman, Jack and Nelle. A BONFIRE, a wind-up Victrola pla Ella Fitzgerald, bottles of wine. Jack and Nelle dance. T toasts Jack drunkenly.
My man, my hero, my talented... My  man...
You said that.
You are the hardest worker, the most  unsung talent I know. As Nelle passes  by on her way to London to sell her  book which needs no selling, may a  little of her success rub off on  both of us.
Jack laughs.
Here, here!
Nelle tries to smack Truman but can't catch him. The song changes to a slow one. Jack and Truman dance sweetly toge Nelle sits on the sand and watches.
Breakfast. Truman and Nelle are sitting -- Nelle has a sm envelope in her hand. Truman is obviously uncomfortable. Jack delivers a platter of omelettes to the table:
(to Truman) When was the last time you wrote  back to him?
I don't know.
What's this?
A letter for your boyfriend I was  asked to deliver.
From Perry.
Let's have it.
Jack sits. Nelle opens the letter, reads:

"Dear Friend Truman. Where are you?  Read this item in a medical  dictionary: "Death by hanging is  caused by asphyxia, by fracture of  the cervical vertebrae, by laceration  of the trachea." Not too comforting  as we lost our appeal. Missing you --  alone and desirous of your presence.  Your amigo, Perry."
Pause.
Mr. Shawn told me about the court  decision yesterday.
I was wondering why you were in such  a good mood. Surely, I thought, it's  not because I finished my little  book.
That's a terrible thing to say.
Jack looks out at the ocean.
(to no one in  particular) I used to write him all the time.  I've been so focused lately on the  book.
Truman and Nelle carry her bags down the front walk towar waiting TAXI.
Jack says I'm using Perry, but he  also thinks I fell in love with him  when I was in Kansas. How both of  those things can be true is beyond  me.
Did you? Fall in love with him.
Silence as they load the bags into the trunk.
Truman? --

I don't know how to answer that...  It's as if Perry and I started life  in the same house. One day he stood  up and walked out the back door while  I walked out the front. With some  different choices, he's the man I  might have become.
Are you kidding me?
Truman shrugs, doesn't answer. Nelle kisses him.
Be nice to Jack. Sometimes I think  he's what I like about you best.
(smiles) I'll see you at the reading in New  York.
The sixteenth.
Nelle gets in the taxi, then leans her head out the windo
Truman. Honestly. Are you going back  to Kansas because you care about  Perry or because you need information  before he's killed?
Can't it be both?
No. I don't think it can be.
She drives away. Truman watches her go. He turns back up  toward the house, stops a moment to pick a FLOWER from th bushes at the front gate.
A Guard walks down the corridor carrying a SINGLE FLOWER. delivers it to Perry, then walks off. Perry is confused. hears FOOTSTEPS approaching, but can't see who it is.
Hey, buddy. Thanks.

More footsteps. CAMERA on Perry as the footsteps finally  arrive outside his cell. He's shocked. REVERSE onto Truman, looking tanned, healthy, very blond. holds a STACK OF BOOKS with a BOW on top. He smiles.

LONG SHOT of dimly lit corridor, light spilling out from  each cell. A ROW GUARD walks the hall. We hear voices  murmuring. SIX MORE GUARDS arrive at the top of the stairs. The ROW  GUARD walks over, unlocks the GATE to let them in.
Perry is looking at the cover of a BOOK -- "WALDEN POND." Other books sit next to Perry on the cot. Among them -- W CATHER's "MY ANTONIA", also "GREAT EXPECTATIONS" --
What was he in jail for?
They said it was not paying his taxes.  But really for being an outsider --  refusing to go along.
Perry nods, looks at the other books.
You don't have to read any of these  if you don't want to. But I thought  you'd like something decent. You're  much too smart for adventure  magazines.
Through the bars of Perry's cell, we can see the SIX GUAR enter Lowell Lee Andrew's cell (diagonally across the  corridor). The ROW GUARD appears at Perry's cell.
Lock-down while Lowell goes to  solitary. Nobody in or out. (to Truman) You want in or out?
Truman looks at Perry, then back to the Guard.
In.

location: KSP, DEATH ROW, LOWELL LEE ANDREW'S CELL

text: The SIX GUARDS start to pack up Andrews cell while he sit on the cot and watches.

Perry and Truman talk very QUIETLY. (Throughout this scen we see in the background, across the corridor, the mostly obscured cell of Andrews. We see his incredibly FAT LEG b shackled, his belongings being packed in boxes.)
Everyone says he's a genius. I don't  think he's a genius. He's rich and  he went to college -- like any of us  would've if we got the chance. He  came home for Christmas and shot his  parents --
-- in front of the television.
You remember the story --
They were watching Father Knows Best.
They look at each other and smile. Then:
I won't be sorry to see him go. Always  correcting my grammar.
They watch Andrews being shackled in the background.
Now -- Dick and me -- we're next in  line.
Truman regards Perry, who looks down.
I'm so sorry I've been away.
It was a long time.
I know.
I wish you could come next week,  when they take him out to the Corner,  but the whole prison shuts down.
I have to be in New York anyway.
Perry nods.
How's the book going?
Very slowly.
Will you show it to me?
I've hardly written anything.
One of the six guards CLANGS Andrews' cell bars with his  stick.
Ready.
The ROW GUARD opens the cell door. Andrews is led out, ar and legs shackled, into the corridor.
Keep your head high, buddy.
Alright now.
...or they won't be able to rope you  under your fat fucking chin.
Andrews is led past Perry's cell. He looks in at Perry.
Next!
Andrews shuffles down the hall. Perry watches him go. On  Truman watching Perry. We hear the GATE slam shut.
Packed. Nelle stands with William Shawn, who receives wel wishers. BEN BARON enters, seeing Nelle.
(loudly, over the  hubbub) Hello Hollywood. That's quite a bundle  you sold your book for.
Nelle is embarrassed, mostly for Baron, to have the issue money brought up publicly.
Well...
Baron moves past, Nelle smiles politely, whispers to Shaw
What a gentleman.

Truman sits alone. In the background, we can HEAR the noi of the huge crowd gathering in the theater. Truman wears MOST STYLISH LITERARY OUTFIT: a gorgeous dark green Knize SUIT over a black cashmere turtleneck sweater, and horn-r GLASSES (which we've never seen him wear before). He's frozen with anticipation, nervousness. After several moments a THEATER ASSISTANT opens the door.
Mr. Capote. Can I get you anything?
No. (clears his throat) Thank you.
The assistant leaves. We hear the crowd quiet down. Truma rises slowly, walks through the door to the backstage are We hear William Shawn on stage.
Welcome New Yorkers...
Shawn pauses briefly for a laugh that doesn't come. Truma continues walking toward the backstage curtains.
Thank you for coming to the first  public reading, the first offering  of any kind, of Truman Capote's new  work "In Cold Blood." Our magazine --
Truman walks on stage. Loud applause. Shawn sees him, sli back to his seat. Truman walks over to the podium, takes the enormous crowd. Once it is completely quiet:
Hello. My name is Truman Capote.
People laugh and applaud loudly.
Perry, eating dinner alone at his table, looks up. We HEA LOUD ENGINE revving outside.
A FRONT-LOADER TRACTOR drives into the warehouse. A PRISO POLICE CAR parks outside the warehouse. Guards get the  enormous Lowell Lee Andrews, shackled, from the back seat walk him inside.
C/U on Perry, now standing on his chair and watching out tiny window.
Truman on stage reading.
Perry Smith's voice was both gentle  and prim -- a voice that, though  soft, manufactured each sound exactly --  ejected it like a smoke ring issuing  from a parson's mouth.
Perry watches through his window. From inside the warehou we hear the gallows TRAP DOOR spring and CLATTER. On Perr
Truman reading. Utter silence except for his voice.

The village of Holcomb stands on the  high wheat plains of western Kansas,  a lonesome area that other Kansans  call "out there." Until one morning  in mid-November 1959, few Americans --  in fact, few Kansans -- had ever  heard of Holcomb. Like the waters of  the [Arkansas] river, like the  motorists on the highway...  exceptional happenings had never  stopped there.
We see the outside wall with Perry and Dick's faces peeri out through their tiny windows.
The TRACTOR emerges through the warehouse doors. It carri in its FRONT SHOVEL the enormous, dead BODY of ANDREWS co by a BLACK CLOTH.
Truman reading. The audience completely still.

The four coffins, which quite filled  the small, flower-crowded parlor,  were to be sealed at the funeral  services -- very understandably, for  the effect... was disquieting. Nancy  wore her dress of cherry-red velvet,  her brother a bright plaid shirt;  the parents were more sedately  attired, Mr. Clutter in navy-blue  flannel, his wife in navy-blue crepe;  and -- and it was this especially  that lent the scene an awful aura --  the head of each was completely  encased in cotton, a swollen cocoon  twice the size of an ordinary blown- up balloon, and the cotton, because  it had been sprayed with a glossy  substance, twinkled like Christmas- tree snow.
The TRACTOR rolls the body into the BED of a waiting PICK TRUCK.
Perry watches through his window.
Truman reading. The audience transfixed.

Imagination, of course, can open any  door -- turn the key and let terror  walk right in. [One] Tuesday, at  dawn, a carload of... strangers,  ignorant of the local disaster --  were startled by what they saw as  they crossed the prairies and passed  through Holcomb: windows ablaze,  almost every window in almost every  house, and, in the brightly lit rooms,  fully clothed people, even entire  families, who had sat the whole night  wide awake, watchful, listening. Of  what were they frightened? "It might  happen again."
He closes his manuscript. Several moments of SILENCE, the thunderous APPLAUSE.

Truman's dressing room. Packed with well-wishers drinking from bottles of CHAMPAGNE, smoking, toasting, shouting to heard. Truman in the corner with Christopher Isherwood, B BARON others, laughing. A LITERARY ENTHUSIAST approaches, leans in.
Your portrait of those men was  terrifying. Terrifying.
Thank you.
Truman and Isherwood watch him walk away.
Your hairpiece is terrifying.
I was going to say the same thing!
Truman laughs loudly. We SEE Nelle look over from across room at her friend having the time of his life.
Truman is hung over but immensely gratified. He's with Sh
Everyone was there.
Tennessee loved it.
Of course he did.
Should we do more? I was terrified,  but --
No, Now we get to withhold while  everyone else talks. Let them do the  work.
Truman is barely able to suppress his excitement.
This book is going to change  everything. It'll change how people  see you as a writer. It'll change  how people write. You'll finish by  October?
I think so. You know they're scheduled  for next month?
Hanging. Yes. I'll commit as many  issues as it takes to publish. Three.  As many as it takes.
I'm flying to Kansas tomorrow. I'll  get Perry to talk --
Honestly, what's he got to lose?
Truman smiles at the joke, then stops himself.
It really is too awful.  Institutionalized sadism.
Shawn nods.
You'll be able to finish now.
As strange as it may sound to you,  I'm going to miss him.
Over black -- the sound of a JET airplane -- loud, then  passing.
Truman, flushed, out of breath, stands outside Perry's ce He's just arrived. He holds a FOLDED-UP NEWSPAPER. Perry  sits at his table reading LEGAL DOCUMENTS.
When did you hear?
Perry looks up, mistaking Truman's state for shared  enthusiasm. He smiles widely.
Two days ago.
The Guard opens the cell for Truman. Perry holds up one o the DOCUMENTS.
It's what we've been waiting for. A  stay of execution to make a federal  appeal.
Truman enters. Perry goes to him and hugs him tightly.
All thanks to you.
On Truman, shocked, being hugged.
Truman sits on the bed, his coat still on, watching Perry hyped up, talking, walking around the cell.
Kansas's had it in for me for ten  years -- in prison the first time,  at that trial, here. They can't corner  me now. Not till the U.S. Government  says so --
Perry, sit down. For a minute. (Perry sits) I need you to talk to me...

We've got all the time in the world  to talk. About everything. I've been  thinking about Ricardo. You need to  stop sending him those trashy books.  I won't even mention the pornography. (getting up) I realize he might have trouble  grasping the literature you gave me,  but those books only exacerbate the  problem -- only 'heighten' or  'intensify' it. Maybe we should start  him on a program...
Perry.
Give him the simple novels first --
Perry.
Perry stops.
I know what exacerbate means.
Okay. I thought in case...
There is not a word, or a sentence,  or a concept, that you can illuminate  for me. There is one singular reason  that I keep coming here --
Truman --
...November 14th, 1959. Three years  ago. Three years. That's all I want  to hear from you.
Pause.
I've asked you not to --
(stands up) This is ridiculous. (to the Guard) I'm ready. (to Perry) I have a plane to catch. I found  your sister in Tacoma. Maybe she'll  talk to me about something useful.
Don't go out there.
The Guard lets Truman out of the cell.
Please don't go out there.
The Guard shuts the door.
This is my work, Perry. I'm working.  When you want to tell me what I need  to hear, you let me know.
He walks off down the hall. The GATE slams shut.
Cheaply built ranch house. LINDA MURCHAK (30) walks in th kitchen back door, shuts it.
They'll play outside a while longer.

Mrs. Murchak looks like a female Perry, dark and small,  attractive and nervous. Through the window, we see THREE  LITTLE CHILDREN playing on a DECREPIT JUNGLE GYM in the y Truman sits at the table, leafing through a PHOTO ALBUM.
I don't want them to see that.
They've never seen these pictures?
(shakes her head) Too many questions.

She joins Truman again at the table. We see an OLD PHOTO of the SMITH FAMILY -- Linda at age 8 Perry (5); their older sister, June; their brother Frank; and the parents: Florence (American Indian) and John (Iri in front of their rundown truck on a desolate road.
June's dead. Frank shot himself. Now  Perry's did what he did. I suppose  I'm next. Some ruination will visit  me.
I don't think life works that way.
It does in this family.
Truman turns the page. A PICTURE of Perry (3) and Linda  HOLDING HANDS and splashing in a big mud-puddle in the ra Linda is smiling at Perry, who is naked, laughing.
I used to love him. He was my little  doll.
He turns the page. A PICTURE of Perry (6) and Linda sitti on the back steps of a shack, poking with a stick at some in the dirt. After a moment, she gets up, clears coffee c
He scares me now.
When was the last time you saw him?
Ten years.
She picks up the album to put it away.
Do you think I could borrow one of  those pictures?
(hands it to him) Take the whole thing. I don't want'em  anymore. (then) Just... Perry doesn't know where I  live. He thinks we're still in  Portland. Please don't tell him we're  not.
(he already has) Alright.
Don't be taken in by my brother.  He's got this sensitive side he'll  show. You believe he's gentle, so  easily hurt. But he'd just as soon  kill you as shake your hand. I believe  that.
Truman slows for a moment as he passes Hickock's cell.
Hello handsome.
Hickock just stares at him. Truman, unnerved, moves on to Perry's cell.
Perry doing pushups. He sees Truman and stops. He stands. The Row Guard approaches.
You want to go in?
Truman regards Perry for a few moments, then:
Yes
The Guard unlocks the door. Perry STARTS TO MOVE toward i The Guard SLAMS it shut.
What's the name of your book?
No response. Perry can barely control his anger.
What's the name of your book?
I don't...
What's the name of your book?
I don't know what you're talking  about.
Perry picks up a cut-out ARTICLE from the NY Times from h desk. He reads.
"Truman Capote read last night before  a packed audience from his non-fiction  book IN COLD BLOOD."
He looks at Truman.
More? (reads) "The true-crime novel tells of killers  Richard Hickock and Perry Smith, who  brutally murdered a Kansas family  three years ago."
Who sent that to you?
Perry doesn't answer.
Who sent that to you?
That's not your goddamn business.
It is my business, because it's not  true. The organizers of the reading  needed a title. They picked one -- a  sensational one, I admit -- to attract  a crowd.
They picked it.
Yes.
That's not your title.
I haven't chosen one yet.
Perry stares at him, not believing.
How could I choose --
You pretend to be my friend...
How could I choose a title when you  still haven't told me what happened  that night? How could I? I couldn't  possibly.
Long pause. Truman reaches in his breast pocket and extra a PHOTO (the one of Perry and Linda splashing in the pudd
I have something from your sister.
He hands it through the bars to Perry. Perry takes it.
She misses you.
Perry looks at the photo. After a few moments, Truman tur to the Guard.
It's alright. I'll go in.
The Guard unlocks the cell. Truman enters. The Guard lock up, walks away. Perry is still looking at the PHOTO.

I'm sorry. I should have told you  what they made me call the book. (touches Perry's arm) I couldn't pretend to be your friend.  The truth is, I can't help wanting  to be. (silence, then:) You don't have to tell me anything  if you don't want to.
Perry looks at the photo of himself and his sister for a  long time.
Look at my belly.
Perry sits on the bed. Then, almost to himself:
There must be something wrong with  us. To do what we did.
