Truman waits him out, sitting on the chair. Finally, Perr looks at him. When Perry speaks, it is quietly, completel matter-of-fact.

We heard there was ten thousand  dollars in that house. Once we'd  tied up everybody and searched all  over, I knew the guy who told us  about it was wrong. There wasn't any  money. But Dick wouldn't believe it.  He went tearing through the house  again, banging on the walls, looking  for a safe. He said when he was done,  he was going to come up to Nancy's  room and have his way with her. I  wouldn't allow it. I told him that.  I sat with Nancy.
Perry and Nancy. Perry sits quietly on the edge of Nancy' bed. A SMALL BEDSIDE LAMP softly illuminates a portion of the room. We hear Dick banging around downstairs.
It was nice in there.
The scene is almost sweet, until we see that Nancy's legs and hands are TIED and her mouth is TAPED.
Perry talking to Truman.

Dick came to get me and we turned  out the lights and went down to the  basement, where we had Mr. Clutter  and the boy. Dick kept saying "No  witnesses." I figured if I just waited  him out he'd give up and leave them  tied up there. We'd drive all night,  they'd never find us. Mr. Clutter's  wrists were tied to a pipe over his  head. He looked like he was hurt, so  I cut him down.
HERBERT CLUTTER is bound and taped, his hands tied to a P on the LOW CEILING. Perry CUTS the rope with a HUNTING KN catches hold of Herb Clutter, lowers him onto a mattress on the floor.
Perry talking to Truman.

We put a box there on the floor so  he'd be more comfortable. He asked  if his wife and daughter were alright  and I said they were fine, they were  ready to go to sleep. I told him it  wasn't long till morning when somebody  would find them. (beat) He was looking at me. Just... looking  at me. Looking at my eyes. Like he  expects me to kill him -- expects me  to be the kind of person who would  kill him. I was thinking -- this  nice man, he's scared of me. I was  ashamed. I mean, I thought he was a  kind man, a good... a gentleman. I  thought so right up to the moment I  cut his throat. I didn't realize  what I'd did till I heard the sound.
Herb Clutter gurgling on the floor.
Like some one drowning under water.
Perry and Truman. Silence, then:
I was staring at him, bleeding on  the floor. I told Dick to finish him  off, but he wouldn't do it. We  couldn't leave Mr. Clutter like that,  so I got the shotgun.
Perry approaches with a SHOTGUN. He aims and SHOOTS him i the face.

location: CLUTTER HOUSE, ANOTHER PART OF THE BASEMENT

text: KENYON CLUTTER (15) is bound and gagged on an old sofa, a pillow under his head. A flashlight illuminates his face. shotgun enters frame, FIRES. An enormous BURST of LIGHT.

location: CLUTTER HOUSE, HERB AND BONNIE'S ROOM

text: Bonnie Clutter (40's, small and thin) tied up on her bed. Moonlight through the window.
We went to Mrs. Clutter's room.
The DOOR opens. Perry and Dick walk in with a flashlight. Perry points the shotgun at Bonnie's face, FIRES. A BURST LIGHT.

Perry and Dick enter Nancy's room, shine the flashlight o her face. She looks at Perry. She has been crying. After moment, she TURNS HER FACE to the wall, as if she knows w is coming and doesn't want to watch it. Perry AIMS the sh at the back of her head. The FLASHLIGHT switches OFF. The shotgun FIRES. A BURST of LIGHT.
Perry and Truman. Perry still on the bed. Truman sits, no moving, on the chair. Silence.
Then we drove off.
Silence. Perry looks at Truman.
What do you think of me now?
No answer. Then:
Added up, how much money did you get  from the Clutters?
Perry thinks.
Between forty and fifty dollars.
Truman nods. They sit there for a long time.
FADE IN: Hands typing on a MANUAL TYPEWRITER. Truman typing at the desk. He stops, removes the page fro the typewriter, places it on top of a SMALL STACK OF PAGE He sits back.
Truman in his seat, sips a drink. He looks out the window
Truman walks with his TRAVEL BAG on his shoulder. He take out his KEYS and turns up the steps to his house.

location: TRUMAN AND JACK'S HOUSE, FRONT HALL

text: Truman opens the door.
Jack.
No answer. He walks down the hall to the BEDROOM.

Truman enters, drops his travel bag on the bed, zips it o removes a SMALL STACK OF TYPED PAGES. He walks to his des On the desk, we see a HUGE STACK OF TYPED PAGES with a ti page on top which reads: IN COLD BLOOD. Truman lifts the  HUGE STACK, places the SMALL STACK under it. He smooths o the pages, then steps back from it. He calls out:
Jack.
No answer. On Truman, standing in the middle of his room. has finished all that he can finish, and is lost as to wh to do next.
TITLE UP:          "One Year Later"

head_text.subj: OVER BLACK WE HEAR THE FOLLOWING DIALOGUE COME UP SLOWLY

text: ...I want to give it to you. The  truth is, I'm desperate to be done  with it...
Truman on the PHONE, in pajamas, looking in the FRIDGE.
Mr. Shawn, I... I've spent four years  of my life on this book... They got  a stay of execution yesterday...  Another, yes....
He gets out a jar of BONNET BABY FOOD CUSTARD and starts eat it. Truman finds a bottle of J&B on the counter and p a shot in his custard.
Supreme Court....
He stirs the custard, eats it.
...It's harrowing -- all I want is  to write the ending and there's no  fucking end in sight... No. No, I  haven't been drinking again...
Truman sits on the bed with a glass of bourbon, staring a the television. An empty jar of BABY CUSTARD sits on the  bedside table.
Truman on the bed, the television still on, another drink We hear a DOORBELL. We hear Jack walk down the hall, answ the door, shut the door. Jack enters with a TELEGRAM.
I don't know how you can eat that.  Perhaps if you weren't drinking so  much you wouldn't have to.
No response. Jack turns down the television, opens the  telegram.

(reads) "Dear friend Truman. Haven't heard  from you in such a long while. Please  help find new lawyer. If not, Dick  will have to write Supreme Court  brief himself. Our last appeal. What  a pair of wretched creatures. Please  help. Your amigo? Perry."
Pause. Jack looks at Truman.
Your amigo.
Truman stares back. Finally, he turns back to the televis
Put it with the others.
Jack goes to the DESK and places the telegram on top of a LARGE PILE OF TELEGRAMS, all from Perry -- all, we should assume, unanswered. Jack walks out. Truman sips his drink.
Truman at the desk, still in PAJAMAS, typing. Jack enters wearing a TUXEDO, reads over Truman's shoulder. We see: "...unable to find laywer despite extensive search. So so All best, Truman."
You tried?
Truman extracts the page from the typewriter, folds it, a puts it in an envelope. He takes a sip of his BOURBON.
(walking out) You need to get ready.
Truman and Jack are driven. Both wear TUXEDOS and OVERCOA Truman drinks.
Driving. Truman and Jack sit in silence, then:
At least pretend for Nelle that you're  having a good time tonight.
The limo turns a corner and we see an ENORMOUS CROWD in f of a THEATER. On the marquee it says: "Opening tonight -
It is COLD. Truman and Jack's limo pulls up. An USHER ope their DOOR.
Truman, obviously drunk, preens and poses on the red carp for the CAMERAS. Jack watches from the side.
Huge party in progress. Nelle walks through the crowd. Pe turn to her saying: "Congratulations"; "Wonderful". She f Truman sitting at the BAR, receiving a new drink.
Nelle.
She looks UNCOMFORTABLY DOLLED UP for the premiere of her movie.
I thought I'd find you here.
(to the bartender) Please, another.
He hands Nelle his drink, receives another. After a momen
How are you?
Terrible.
Beat.
I'm sorry to hear that.
Well. It's torture. Torture... (he drinks) ...what they're doing to me.
Uh-huh.
Now the Supreme Court. Can you believe  it? If they win this appeal I will  have a complete nervous breakdown. I  may never recover. Just pray things  turn my way.
It must be hard.
It's torture. They're torturing me.
I see.
Nelle regards him for a moment.
And how'd you like the movie, Truman.
She puts her drink down on the bar and walks away. Truman turns back to the bartender, shrugs.
I frankly don't know what the fuss  is about.
On Truman, alone at the bar.

location: STREET, OUTSIDE TRUMAN AND JACK'S HOUSE

text: FADE UP on a PAPER BOY riding his BIKE down the street. N buds are on the trees. It is SPRING. The BOY wears a NEW  YORK TIMES bag slung over his chest and is tossing copies the paper. One of them lands on Truman and Jack's stoop.
Phone RINGING. Truman asleep.

location: TRUMAN AND JACK'S HOUSE, JACK'S TINY OFFICE

text: Jack is writing, longhand, at his desk. PHONE is ringing. Jack notices that his door is slightly ajar. He kicks it  shut. The ringing is much quieter. He keeps writing.
Truman asleep. PHONE ringing. He wakes up, groggy, answer
Hello.
Mr. Capote?
Yes?
I have a call from Mr. Perry Smith  in the Kansas Correctional System.  Will you accept charges?
Pause.
Mr. Truman Capote?
Yes.
Will you accept charges?
Oh. (no way out of this) Uh... Yes.
You'll accept charges?
Yes.
Mr. Smith, you're on the line.
Now Truman's awake. We hear a series of CLICKS, then:
Hello.
Truman can't bring himself to speak.
Hello? I can't -- (to someone) This doesn't seem -- (we hear Perry clicking  the cradle, then:) Operator, I don't think you put me --
I'm here.
Beat.
Truman.
Hello, Perry.
They let me make a couple phone calls  before I go down to Holding... You  heard the Supreme Court rejected the  appeal.
I didn't... I hadn't heard that.
Yeah.
Pause.
I'm sorry.
Yeah. They let me make two phone  calls.
Truman doesn't know what to say.
We've got a date set for the  Warehouse, Dick and me. Two weeks  and... Finito. April 14.
Beat.
Will you visit me? Truman. Will you  come visit?
I don't know if I can. I'll try. (beat) I don't know if I can.
We hear over the line a GUARD in the background:
Time, Smith. Hang it up.
Please visit me, Truman. Just...
Time. Smith.
CLICK. Truman sits very still, the phone in his hand.
Perry and Dick being shackled, their belongings packed in boxes. One of the GUARDS in Perry's cell CLANGS the bars  with his STICK.
Ready.
Perry lies alone on his cot. The DOOR opens, KRUTCH enter with a GUARD.
Perry.
Perry sits up. Krutch sits on the one chair. The Guard st by the door, takes out a PAD and STUBBY PENCIL.
You're allowed three names of people  you'd like to witness tomorrow. If  there's anybody you want, tell me  now.
Truman Capote.
Krutch nods to the Guard who writes the name down. Krutch waits, then:
Anybody else?
Perry SHAKES HIS HEAD.

In a chair near the window, Truman sits awake in his paja unable to sleep, completely unable to decide what to do. watches Jack sleep. A long time -- then Truman walks to t closet, gets out a travel bag, starts to pack.
A PLANE takes off.
Truman sits next to William Shawn, who looks exhausted. T STEWARDESS is approaching with the DRINKS CART. She colle an empty BABY CUSTARD JAR from Truman's tray.
You want anything?
Truman shakes his head.
OUTSIDE LIGHTS switch on as it gets dark.
Perry sits alone. The door opens and a Guard brings in hi LAST MEAL: three hot dogs, french fries, an ice cream sun a strawberry soda. The Guard sets it down on the chair.
Thank you. (then) You sent the telegram to his hotel?
Hours ago.
Perry looks at the CLOCK on the wall: it's after 8pm.
May I make a phone call?

location: HOTEL ROOM, MUEHLEBACH HOTEL, KANSAS CITY

text: PHONE ringing. The CLOCK rads 8:55pm. Empty drinks glasse a custard jar. Truman lies curled in a fetal position on BED. Shawn walks the floor, exasperated.
That's him again.
Truman is immobile. Phone still rings.
We've never even met. It is utterly  inappropriate for me to be talking  to him.
Shawn gives up, PICKS UP the phone.
Yes... I'm sorry, he's out, gone  out... I'm not sure when...
Krutch walks with a TELEGRAM PAGE in hand. A Guard follow They pass a WALL CLOCK: 9:40pm.
Krutch and Guard enter Perry's cell. Perry hasn't touched his meal.
You got a telex.
Perry nods. Krutch reads:
"Perry. Unable to visit today because  not permitted. Always your friend,  Truman." (apologetically) That's it.
It's not true, is it?
Krutch hesitates a moment, then SHAKES his head.
Nelle on the PHONE looking at a TELEGRAM. The kitchen CLO reads 10:20pm. She waits a moment till the line is answer
Mr. Shawn? It's Nelle... I just got  this telegram, has he seen it?
INTERCUT with William Shawn on the phone in Truman's hote room. A TELEGRAM lies on the DESK. Truman lies on the bed
He won't look at it.
Would you put him on please?
He won't talk.
(calmly) Mr. Shawn, if you have to hold him  down and put the phone on his ear, I  need to speak to him.
Shawn, terrifically uncomfortable, walks over to Truman a holds the phone out to him.
It's Nelle.
A moment, then Truman takes the phone. On Truman's face. hear, through the receiver, Nelle:
Truman.
Truman finally breathes out.
Perry is led, SHACKLED, into a holding cell on the ground floor of the Death Row Building. Dick is already there,  seated, shackled. We HEAR PERRY'S VOICE:
"Miss Nelle Harper Lee and Truman  Capote: Sorry that Truman was unable  to make it here at the prison for a  brief word prior to necktie party...
The CLOCK reads 11:05pm. Through the WINDOW, we see activ in the Gallows Warehouse across the yard.
...Whatever his reason for not showing  up, I want him to know that I cannot  condemn him for it and understand...
Perry makes eye contact with the Guard, who CHEWS GUM. Th Guard checks through the SMALL WINDOW in the door, then  approaches Perry, places a STICK OF GUM in Perry's mouth. Perry CHEWS.
...Not much time left but want you  both to know that I've been sincerely  grateful for your friendship through  the years and everything else...
Truman opens the door to the other part of the suite, whe William Shawn is waiting. Truman is fully dressed and rea Perry's VOICE:
...I'm not very good at these  things....
TAXICAB pulls up to the prison gates. Perry's VOICE:
I have become extremely affectionate  toward you both. But, harness time.  Adios amigos. Your friend, Perry."
Clock reads 11:35pm. Truman sits with Shawn. Truman is lo at the TELEGRAM from Perry. He folds it, puts it in the b pocket of his jacket. Krutch approaches.
I didn't think I'd be seeing you  again. (then) You can visit for a few minutes.
Truman stands, turns to Shawn, still seated.
No.
Come with me.
Truman. No.
Truman goes alone.
Perry, Dick, a Guard. Krutch lets Truman in.
Five minutes.
He exits, closes the door. Truman doesn't know what to sa
(without rancor) He returns. Long time.
I don't know what you must think of  me.
You haven't been foremost on my mind  lately. As you can imagine.
Dick looks at Perry and smiles. Perry chews his gum and s back, then looks to Truman who seems upset.
You got the letter?
Yes.
It's true. I mean I understand why  you didn't want to come. I wouldn't  be here either if I didn't have to.
You got that right.
Silence.
You know Ricardo donated his eyes to  science? Next week, some blind man  will be seeing what Dick used to  see.

(laughs) He'd be better off the way he was.  What I've seen hasn't been so nice  to look at -- but I guess it's better  than nothing. (he shrugs, to Truman) They came around with a form. (beat) Hey. You'll be walking down the street  one day in Denver, wherever -- and  suddenly these eyes will be staring  at you. Wouldn't that be something?
(quietly) It would be.
Krutch opens the door.
Time.
Truman looks at the clock: 11:50pm. Truman turns to Perry and Dick. Perry stands.
You'll be watching?
I don't know. Do you want me to?
I'd like to have a friend there.
Okay. Then I will.
Truman looks down, starts to cry.
It's alright.
I did everything I could.
Okay.
I truly did.
I know.
Truman nods, wipes his eyes.
Goodbye, Perry.
You're not rid of me yet. I'll see  you in a few minutes.
Truman goes. On Perry watching him leave.

Huge. Dirt floor. Wooden gallows. TWENTY MEN stand around some smoking. Some are silent. Some whisper quietly. Journalists. Also, Alvin Dewey and the KBI men: Church an Nye. Krutch in front of the gallows with a CHAPLAIN. At t foot of the gallows steps, the EXECUTIONER -- thin, older too-large pin-striped suit and stained cowboy hat. Truman William Shawn. HEADLIGHTS, then a PRISON CAR enters, stops. Dick is extr from the back seat. He stands, looks at the CROWD, then a the GALLOWS. The Guards nudge him forward.
CLOCK reads 12:05pm. Perry sits alone looking at his hand We HEAR A TRAP DOOR SPRING and CLATTER. Perry looks up.
Light rain outside. Perry in the back seat being driven a the yard. He looks out his window, sees a PICKUP TRUCK dr out of the Corner Warehouse. On it: a BODY covered by a B CLOTH.
The PRISON CAR enters, stops. Perry is removed from the b seat. He stands, looks at the assembled men, looks at Tru He's nudged forward. As he passes DEWEY, he extends his h
Nice to see you.
Dewey is caught off-guard so shakes his hand. Perry is le to the base of the gallows.

Perry Edward Smith. (reads) "For the crime of murder in the first  degree, by order of the Court of  Finney County and the Supreme Court  of the sovereign State of Kansas,  you are sentenced to hang until you  die." (then) You can say something if you want.
(quietly, to Krutch) Is there anybody from the family  here?
No.
Perry is disappointed by this information.
Well. Tell them... (he look out at  everyone) I can't remember what I was going to  say for the life of me...
He stops. Several moments. Krutch can't tell if he's done. Finally, Krutch nods to t Guard. Perry is led up the STEPS. The Chaplain follows.
Though I walk through the valley of  the shadow of death, I will fear no  evil, for thou art with me.
The Executioner puts the NOOSE around Perry's neck. Perry chews his gum. Executioner opens a BLACK CLOTH SACK. Perry looks at the Chaplain reading prayers, looks at the crowd, at Truman.
Thy rod and thy staff, they comfort  me.
The BLACK SACK goes over Perry's head. Truman watches. He stands next to Alvin Dewey.
Thou preparest a table before me in  the presence of mine enemies. Thou  annointest my head with oil.
The Executioner pulls the handle, Perry drops.
My cup runneth over.
On Truman. Then a WIDE SHOT of the inside of the Warehous twenty men watching Perry Smith hang, the Chaplain readin
The SOUND of a TELEPHONE RINGING, as heard through the  receiver. We HEAR the CLICK of the phone being PICKED UP, then, after a moment, a VOICE:
Hello.
Truman sits on the edge of the bed in his WET OVERCOAT, a if he'd walked in the rain.
Someday I'll tell you about it. For  the moment, I'm too shattered.
Pause.
They're dead, Truman. You're alive.
It was a terrible experience and I  will never get over it. (then) There wasn't anything I could have  done to save them.
We hear Nelle light a cigarette.
Maybe not.
We hear her exhale slowly.
But the fact is, you didn't want to.
On Truman,
Truman, seated on the aisle, next to William Shawn. After long silence, he extracts from his leather briefcase a PA wrapped in BROWN PAPER. Hands it to Truman.
It came to the hotel this morning. I  told them I'd give it to you.

The package says KANSAS STATE PENITENTIARY and is address to Truman. Truman opens it. He takes out PERRY'S NOTEBOOKS -- the DIARY and PERSONAL  DICTIONARY. He opens the Diary. Toward the end, he finds  Perry's final entry. He READS silently. We hear Perry's V
Did we not know we were to die, we  would be children. By knowing it, we  are given the opportunity to mature  in spirit...
Truman turns the page. It's BLANK. He closes the Diary. We CONTINUE to hear Perry's VOICE as Truman takes out a  SNAPSHOT -- the one of Perry (at age 3) and Linda splashi in the puddle.
Some take that opportunity. I hope I  have...
Truman takes out a PENCIL DRAWING Perry did of him. It's  very good, though Truman looks old and weary in it.
Life is only the father of wisdom.  Death is the mother.

Truman finds, at the bottom of the package, his TIE. He t it out, clutches it. Truman grasps for William Shawn's HAND, finds it, holds o tightly. Shawn sits stoically, hoping no one will notice. The CAMERA pulls back, up the aisle. Truman clutches the  tie, and holds on to Shawn's hand, for dear life.

TITLE UP: (each title fades up in succession) In Cold Blood made Truman Capote the most famous writer i America. He never finished another book. The epigraph he chose for his last published work reads:  "More tears are shed over answered prayers than unanswere ones. " He died in 1984 of complications due to alcoholism.
